-How do we work next week? What do we want the cadence of check-ins to be? What sorts of artifact dependencies exist?
-How close can we be to defined templates, defined content types, defined data models and wireframes (for podium) by 01/03?

thank you <@U0HPGQ4KH>!

so along the question of showtime admin vs our own cms, I think our own basic cms is a requirement.  showtime admin is not a database, its a form that collects everything the exhibit needs at any given point to run the exhibit. If we were to use it it would be a completely canned experience, there wouldnt be a search. it would be we need this data to drive the experience. and what is that. someone input this data head of time and we will just display it. There is no search, we already have the data we need. Its very static. We will need a cms even if its a basic form input to a datastore. And there is no requirement that this admin lives in showtime. There would be a link to it, but iframe is over kill and completely unneeded. and no data from our cms would go back into the show for the run of show. Im writing this up in more detail in the software doc, can discuss more tomorrow
Just curious, would we ever be able to share some of this work after it's been scrubbed? Like BrandLab?
good question <@U0J6TE0CA> that’s part of the compensation strcuture - we’re trying to neogtiate portfolio rights
does that impact how you’re approaching the project?  if so, curious of how!
Just wanted to know for down the road, esp with how we showcased BrandLab
its the hope.  Google usually dosnt let anyone talk about the work done with them but we’re well positioned.

Thanks for update <@U0EL0GLEL> Quick follow-up question: With Showtime, can we build an object (e.g. Renewable energy at Google data centers) and associate content types and data fields with it? And just can't perform search? Or are you saying that even creating objects and associating content types with those objects is a no go?

Thru showtime that is all a no go, showtime has the concept of “show” this show is just a form, that has data in it. There is no concept of search. There is no taxonomy. It is just a grouping of data that is sent to the exhibit to run the exhibit. What we need to do is decouple that. The app will need to hit a separate admin api. This would handle the search and return of the data. showtime just doesnt supply a mechanism for this type of data handling
the complexity of our data and modeling is all TBD

Thanks. Making sense. Is the grouping of data that is sent to the exhibit to run the exhibit in that software approach doc? If not, curious what it allows? And do you have an admin approach in mind that is relatively low effort?

text: Right now for the data stored in showtime for running the exhibit im seeing it as a Is it actively running or not. There would be two “shows” setup in showtime. One with active true called “Active show” another called “Hold or screensaver or whatever” and active false. This would tell the system to kick over the front end into the active ready for input mode, vs some sort of screen saver in between the active states. This way when the system times out from lack of input its a simple message sent out that says click over to the other “show” and go dormant, or some interaction with the touch screen says ready to start and it messages the active state
<@U0HPGQ4KH> only the right 3 in the ceiling work
the rest aren't installed
they're all driven by the same system, but they display only text
thanks <@U02E3CRMA>, are they only active where they are green, or does the green represent content crawling across the full lenght of the slat?

im not seeing there being any other need to store anything in showtime other than this its active or dormant states. showtime is more of a traffic cop than anything. It tells the exhibit to turn on and off, and routes messages around. thats basically all its designed to do. and it can send a set of data to say this is what the exhibit should show for its data, just this data. but we need dynamic data, and searchable data so we skip that part and just keep state inside showtime, active or not
<@U0HP6TFNX> green represents content crawling across

Late into this but I think you all got it. Every time you see a green area, it represents an active area. Active meaning either a screen or a ticker. So it is the hardware that I marked in green.
All other areas that are not green in the bend piece inside of the space are wooden slats, and can therefore never be active.
